I've been browsing the forums for a long long time. I've also been playing KSP for a long long time. I've noticed many posts get edited and removed, as well as many frustrated people complain about various things. Are people still generally upset about things going on? I don't want details because I don't want to break the rules, just curious.

I am active on other sites and ksp resources such as /kspg/, steam etc. But there is no other dedicated KSP forum. Or is there? I don't want to discuss previous problems, just offer solutions.

Just wanted to point out to people the existence of [http://kspfans.freeforums.net/](http://kspfans.freeforums.net/)

It's pretty much a blank slate as of now, but can be made into whatever we want. The #1 rule about the site according to the welcome message is that there's no moderation. So, if anyone wants to join me, I'm going to make an account now. Oh, and might I suggest that you use a different username, if you wish, but it's totally up to you!

See you there!

P.S. I read all the forum rules and there's nothing about posting other KSP resources being against the rules, which is why I posted this.

Good luck with zero moderation and all that brings, have fun with all the [Moderation team infighting], spambots, Thai brides and ...., I hope your parents don't walk past while you're on that site ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Oh and have fun with the personal attacks, the fighting, useless arguing, and other stuff not even tangentially related to KSP, games, science or even sanity ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

You're going to need moderation, not at first but in time, as the Steam forums, Facepunch, somethignawful, and even 4chan have learned, only difference is theirs are less visible ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-06-18T01:21:33Z" title="06/18/2015 01:21  AM" data-short="9 yr">June 18, 2015</time> by sal\_vager**
Nobody likes too much moderation. But none at all is even worse. There always has to be the perfect balance. Just stay reasonable.
Moderation is one thing. Censorship is another.

We do aim for a light touch here as much as possible, rather than act like police enforcing laws we prefer to act like firefighters dealing with emergency calls, though if we see smoke we'll investigate.

Trouble is there are things no one really wants to see, such as two members turning an interesting thread into their personal battleground, or stalking and harassing each other in other peoples threads.

It's also helping no one when members flat out lie about stuff to get others worked up, or complain about "censorship", by all means criticise but back up your claims or take a hike.

Too much moderation would be where the moderators think *they* are basically "the community" and in charge, and just impose their views on others, but that stifles discussion and I like to see varied discussion here.

On many sites the moderators are pretty much "us v them", and are very much apart from the community, rather than being a part of that community, and as a player and member I don't like or want that, so I encourage all the mods to participate, as I think it's better that we're all seen to be here for you guys, not here to just slap members with rules.

I've been on sites where the moderators just enforce rules with no consideration or thought, and it's not fun, stuff like that drove me away, so for as long as I'm here I'll work to keep KSP forum moderation pretty much as it is now, with all the moderators drawn from this community so they know it and care about it and its members.

> 
> Moderation is one thing. Censorship is another.

It is true. I believe profanity, racism, random hatred etc. being deleted is very rightful moderation.

Deleting things simply based on if the moderator dislikes the idea being presented is censorship. I don't really quite think it is right to judge other people's thoughts and opinions but the simple truth is this is squad's forums so it is also squad's rules.

The direction Sal and everyone else is trying to follow is just to keep things reasonable. I really do appreciate this. I suppose the easiest way to keep away from "censorship" here is simply not to encourage it anyways. As in... don't draw so much attention. Stay reasonable.

The only time I ever had a problem with the moderation is someone thought one of my entirely stock crafts actually used mods and tried to change the prefix. In the end everything turned out alright though. The moderation here is a lot better than elsewhere.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-06-18T00:42:41Z" title="06/18/2015 12:42  AM" data-short="9 yr">June 18, 2015</time> by Jon144**

> 
> It is true. I believe profanity, racism, random hatred etc. being deleted is very rightful moderation.
> Deleting things simply based on if the moderator dislikes the idea being presented is censorship. I don't really quite think it is right to judge other people's thoughts and opinions but the simple truth is this is squad's forums so it is also squad's rules.

Those things are dealt with, as are unfounded claims, slander, generally being an arse.

I'll bring up an example here, regex, he's been quite controversial and frequently criticises Squad, but he's still here and hasn't been banned, why do you think that is?

I'll tell you, regex, unlike some other members who claim to be unfairly censored, actually backs up his claims and doesn't make crap up, he criticises but he's never angry and confrontational when he does it, and while he may be a bit of a pain at times, and knows it, he's still a valued member.

You don't see him complaining about censorship, he knows this is Squads house, and he knows how to behave, so even though he criticises his posts are welcome here.

Quick edit:

Some people will scream censorship if *any* of their posts are moderated for *any* reason, as they can never accept they might be the one causing trouble ![;)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)
